trans-unit.target: REST client

trans-unit.source: REST client
trans-unit.target: REST client

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: REST client
trans-unit.target: REST client

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This tutorial teaches you a number of features in .NET Core and the C# language.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial teaches you a number of features in .NET Core and the C# language.

trans-unit.source: You’ll learn:
trans-unit.target: You’ll learn:

trans-unit.source: The basics of the .NET Core Command Line Interface (CLI).
trans-unit.target: The basics of the .NET Core Command Line Interface (CLI).

trans-unit.source: An overview of C# Language features.
trans-unit.target: An overview of C# Language features.

trans-unit.source: Managing dependencies with NuGet
trans-unit.target: Managing dependencies with NuGet

trans-unit.source: HTTP Communications
trans-unit.target: HTTP Communications

trans-unit.source: Processing JSON information
trans-unit.target: Processing JSON information

trans-unit.source: Managing configuration with Attributes.
trans-unit.target: Managing configuration with Attributes.

trans-unit.source: You’ll build an application that issues HTTP Requests to a REST service on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: You’ll build an application that issues HTTP Requests to a REST service on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: You'll read information in JSON format, and convert that JSON packet into C# objects.
trans-unit.target: You'll read information in JSON format, and convert that JSON packet into C# objects.

trans-unit.source: Finally, you'll see how to work with C# objects.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you'll see how to work with C# objects.

trans-unit.source: There are a lot of features in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: There are a lot of features in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Let’s build them one by one.
trans-unit.target: Let’s build them one by one.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.

trans-unit.source: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.
trans-unit.target: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.

trans-unit.source: You can run this application on Windows, Linux, macOS or in a Docker container.
trans-unit.target: You can run this application on Windows, Linux, macOS or in a Docker container.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.

trans-unit.source: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.
trans-unit.target: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.

trans-unit.source: Create the Application
trans-unit.target: Create the Application

trans-unit.source: The first step is to create a new application.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to create a new application.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt and create a new directory for your application.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt and create a new directory for your application.

trans-unit.source: Make that the current directory.
trans-unit.target: Make that the current directory.

trans-unit.source: Type the command "dotnet new" at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Type the command "dotnet new" at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This creates the starter files for a basic “Hello World” application.
trans-unit.target: This creates the starter files for a basic “Hello World” application.

trans-unit.source: Before you start making modifications, let’s go through the steps to run the simple Hello World application.
trans-unit.target: Before you start making modifications, let’s go through the steps to run the simple Hello World application.

trans-unit.source: After creating the application, type "dotnet restore" at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: After creating the application, type "dotnet restore" at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This command runs the NuGet package restore process.
trans-unit.target: This command runs the NuGet package restore process.

trans-unit.source: NuGet is a .NET package manager.
trans-unit.target: NuGet is a .NET package manager.

trans-unit.source: This command downloads any of the missing dependencies for your project.
trans-unit.target: This command downloads any of the missing dependencies for your project.

trans-unit.source: As this is a new project, none of the dependencies are in place, so the first run will download the .NET Core framework.
trans-unit.target: As this is a new project, none of the dependencies are in place, so the first run will download the .NET Core framework.

trans-unit.source: After this initial step, you will only need to run dotnet restore when you add new dependent packages, or update the versions of any of your dependencies.
trans-unit.target: After this initial step, you will only need to run dotnet restore when you add new dependent packages, or update the versions of any of your dependencies.

trans-unit.source: This process also creates the project lock file (project.lock.json) in your project directory.
trans-unit.target: This process also creates the project lock file (project.lock.json) in your project directory.

trans-unit.source: This file helps to manage the project dependencies.
trans-unit.target: This file helps to manage the project dependencies.

trans-unit.source: It contains the local location of all the project dependencies.
trans-unit.target: It contains the local location of all the project dependencies.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to put the file in source control; it will be generated when you run “dotnet restore”.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to put the file in source control; it will be generated when you run “dotnet restore”.

trans-unit.source: After restoring packages, you run “dotnet build”.
trans-unit.target: After restoring packages, you run “dotnet build”.

trans-unit.source: This executes the build engine and creates your application.
trans-unit.target: This executes the build engine and creates your application.

trans-unit.source: Finally, you execute “dotnet run” to run your application.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you execute “dotnet run” to run your application.

trans-unit.source: Adding New Dependencies
trans-unit.target: Adding New Dependencies

trans-unit.source: One of the key design goals for .NET Core is to minimize the size of the .NET framework installation.
trans-unit.target: One of the key design goals for .NET Core is to minimize the size of the .NET framework installation.

trans-unit.source: The .NET Core Application framework contains only the most common elements of the .NET full framework.
trans-unit.target: The .NET Core Application framework contains only the most common elements of the .NET full framework.

trans-unit.source: This application needs more libraries for some of its features.
trans-unit.target: This application needs more libraries for some of its features.

trans-unit.source: You'll add those dependencies into your project.json file.
trans-unit.target: You'll add those dependencies into your project.json file.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to add the `System.Net.Http` package so that your application can make HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to add the `System.Net.Http` package so that your application can make HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to add the `System.Runtime.Serialization.Json` package so your application can process JSON responses.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to add the `System.Runtime.Serialization.Json` package so your application can process JSON responses.

trans-unit.source: Open your project.json file.
trans-unit.target: Open your project.json file.

trans-unit.source: Look for the dependencies section.
trans-unit.target: Look for the dependencies section.

trans-unit.source: You should see one line that looks similar to this:
trans-unit.target: You should see one line that looks similar to this:

trans-unit.source: You'll add two lines to this section to include the two new libraries:
trans-unit.target: You'll add two lines to this section to include the two new libraries:

trans-unit.source: Most code editors will provide completion for different versions of these libraries.
trans-unit.target: Most code editors will provide completion for different versions of these libraries.

trans-unit.source: You'll usually want to use the latest version of any package that you add.
trans-unit.target: You'll usually want to use the latest version of any package that you add.

trans-unit.source: However, it is important to make sure that the versions of all packages match, and that they also match the version of the .NET Core Application framework.
trans-unit.target: However, it is important to make sure that the versions of all packages match, and that they also match the version of the .NET Core Application framework.

trans-unit.source: After you've made these changes, you should run "dotnet restore" again so that those packages are installed on your system.
trans-unit.target: After you've made these changes, you should run "dotnet restore" again so that those packages are installed on your system.

trans-unit.source: Making Web Requests
trans-unit.target: Making Web Requests

trans-unit.source: Now you're ready to start retrieving data from the web.
trans-unit.target: Now you're ready to start retrieving data from the web.

trans-unit.source: In this application, you'll read information from the [GitHub API](https://developer.github.com/v3/).
trans-unit.target: In this application, you'll read information from the [GitHub API](https://developer.github.com/v3/).

trans-unit.source: Let's read information about the projects under the [.NET Foundation](http://www.dotnetfoundation.org/) umbrella.
trans-unit.target: Let's read information about the projects under the [.NET Foundation](http://www.dotnetfoundation.org/) umbrella.

trans-unit.source: You'll start by making the request to the GitHub API to retrieve information on the projects.
trans-unit.target: You'll start by making the request to the GitHub API to retrieve information on the projects.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint you'll use is: [https://api.github.com/orgs/dotnet/repos](https://api.github.com/orgs/dotnet/repos).
trans-unit.target: The endpoint you'll use is: [https://api.github.com/orgs/dotnet/repos](https://api.github.com/orgs/dotnet/repos).

trans-unit.source: You want to retrieve all the information about these projects, so you'll use an HTTP GET request.
trans-unit.target: You want to retrieve all the information about these projects, so you'll use an HTTP GET request.

trans-unit.source: Your browser also uses HTTP GET requests, so you can paste that URL into your browser to see what information you'll be receiving and processing.
trans-unit.target: Your browser also uses HTTP GET requests, so you can paste that URL into your browser to see what information you'll be receiving and processing.

trans-unit.source: You use the `HttpClient` class to make web requests.
trans-unit.target: You use the `HttpClient` class to make web requests.

trans-unit.source: Like all modern .NET APIs, `HttpClient` supports only async methods for its long-running APIs.
trans-unit.target: Like all modern .NET APIs, `HttpClient` supports only async methods for its long-running APIs.

trans-unit.source: Start by making an async method.
trans-unit.target: Start by making an async method.

trans-unit.source: You'll fill in the implementation as you build the functionality of the application.
trans-unit.target: You'll fill in the implementation as you build the functionality of the application.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to add a using statement at the top of your `Main()` method so that the C# compiler recognizes the `Task` type:
trans-unit.target: You'll need to add a using statement at the top of your `Main()` method so that the C# compiler recognizes the `Task` type:

trans-unit.source: If you build your project at this point, you'll get a warning generated for this method, because it does not contain any `await` operators and will run synchronously.
trans-unit.target: If you build your project at this point, you'll get a warning generated for this method, because it does not contain any `await` operators and will run synchronously.

trans-unit.source: Ignore that for now, you'll add `await` operators as you fill in the method.
trans-unit.target: Ignore that for now, you'll add `await` operators as you fill in the method.

trans-unit.source: Next, update the `Main()` method to call this method.
trans-unit.target: Next, update the `Main()` method to call this method.

trans-unit.source: The `ProcessRepositories()` method returns a Task, and you shouldn't exit the program before that task finishes.
trans-unit.target: The `ProcessRepositories()` method returns a Task, and you shouldn't exit the program before that task finishes.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you must use the `Wait()` method to block and wait for the task to finish:
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you must use the `Wait()` method to block and wait for the task to finish:

trans-unit.source: Now, you have a program that does nothing, but does it asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: Now, you have a program that does nothing, but does it asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: Let's go back to the `ProcessRepositories()` method and fill in a first version of it:
trans-unit.target: Let's go back to the `ProcessRepositories()` method and fill in a first version of it:

trans-unit.source: You'll need to also add two new using statements at the top of the file for this to compile:
trans-unit.target: You'll need to also add two new using statements at the top of the file for this to compile:

trans-unit.source: This first version makes a web request to read the list of all repositories under the dotnet foundation organization.
trans-unit.target: This first version makes a web request to read the list of all repositories under the dotnet foundation organization.

trans-unit.source: (The gitHub ID for the .NET Foundation is 'dotnet').
trans-unit.target: (The gitHub ID for the .NET Foundation is 'dotnet').

trans-unit.source: First, you create a new `HttpClient`.
trans-unit.target: First, you create a new `HttpClient`.

trans-unit.source: This object handles the request and the responses.
trans-unit.target: This object handles the request and the responses.

trans-unit.source: The next few lines setup the `HttpClient` for this request.
trans-unit.target: The next few lines setup the `HttpClient` for this request.

trans-unit.source: First, it is configured to accept the GitHub JSON responses.
trans-unit.target: First, it is configured to accept the GitHub JSON responses.

trans-unit.source: This format is simply JSON.
trans-unit.target: This format is simply JSON.

trans-unit.source: The next line adds a User Agent header to all requests from this object.
trans-unit.target: The next line adds a User Agent header to all requests from this object.

trans-unit.source: These two headers are checked by the GitHub server code, and are necessary to retrieve information from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: These two headers are checked by the GitHub server code, and are necessary to retrieve information from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: After you've configured the `HttpClient`, you make a web request, and retrieve the response.
trans-unit.target: After you've configured the `HttpClient`, you make a web request, and retrieve the response.

trans-unit.source: In this first version, you use the `GetStringAsync` convenience method.
trans-unit.target: In this first version, you use the `GetStringAsync` convenience method.

trans-unit.source: This convenience method starts a task that makes the web request, and then when the request returns, it will read the response stream, and extract the content from the stream.
trans-unit.target: This convenience method starts a task that makes the web request, and then when the request returns, it will read the response stream, and extract the content from the stream.

trans-unit.source: The body of the response is returned as a `string`.
trans-unit.target: The body of the response is returned as a `string`.

trans-unit.source: The string is available when the task completes.
trans-unit.target: The string is available when the task completes.

trans-unit.source: The final two lines of this method await that task, and then print the response to the console.
trans-unit.target: The final two lines of this method await that task, and then print the response to the console.

trans-unit.source: Build the app, and run it.
trans-unit.target: Build the app, and run it.

trans-unit.source: The build warning is gone now, because the `ProcessRepositories` now does contain an `await` operator.
trans-unit.target: The build warning is gone now, because the `ProcessRepositories` now does contain an `await` operator.

trans-unit.source: You'll see a long display of JSON formatted text.
trans-unit.target: You'll see a long display of JSON formatted text.

trans-unit.source: Processing the JSON Result
trans-unit.target: Processing the JSON Result

trans-unit.source: At this point, you've written the code to retrieve a response from a web server, and display the text that is contained in that response.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you've written the code to retrieve a response from a web server, and display the text that is contained in that response.

trans-unit.source: Next, let's convert that JSON response into C# objects.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's convert that JSON response into C# objects.

trans-unit.source: The JSON Serializer converts JSON data into C# Objects.
trans-unit.target: The JSON Serializer converts JSON data into C# Objects.

trans-unit.source: Your first task is to define a C# class type to contain the information you use from this response.
trans-unit.target: Your first task is to define a C# class type to contain the information you use from this response.

trans-unit.source: Let's build this slowly, so start with a simple C# type that contains the name of the repository:
trans-unit.target: Let's build this slowly, so start with a simple C# type that contains the name of the repository:

trans-unit.source: Put the above code in a new file called 'repo.cs'.
trans-unit.target: Put the above code in a new file called 'repo.cs'.

trans-unit.source: This version of the class represents the simplest path to process JSON data.
trans-unit.target: This version of the class represents the simplest path to process JSON data.

trans-unit.source: The class name and the member name match the names used in the JSON packet, instead of following C# conventions.
trans-unit.target: The class name and the member name match the names used in the JSON packet, instead of following C# conventions.

trans-unit.source: You'll fix that by providing some configuration attributes later.
trans-unit.target: You'll fix that by providing some configuration attributes later.

trans-unit.source: This class demonstrates another important feature of JSON serialization and deserialization: Not all the fields in the JSON packet are part of this class.
trans-unit.target: This class demonstrates another important feature of JSON serialization and deserialization: Not all the fields in the JSON packet are part of this class.

trans-unit.source: The JSON serializer will ignore information that is not included in the class type being used.
trans-unit.target: The JSON serializer will ignore information that is not included in the class type being used.

trans-unit.source: This feature makes it easier to create types that work with only a subset of the fields in the JSON packet.
trans-unit.target: This feature makes it easier to create types that work with only a subset of the fields in the JSON packet.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've created the type, let's deserialize it.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've created the type, let's deserialize it.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to create a `DataContractJsonSerializer` object.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to create a `DataContractJsonSerializer` object.

trans-unit.source: This object must know the CLR type expected for the JSON packet it retrieves.
trans-unit.target: This object must know the CLR type expected for the JSON packet it retrieves.

trans-unit.source: The packet from GitHub contains a sequence of repositories, so a `List<repo>` is the correct type.
trans-unit.target: The packet from GitHub contains a sequence of repositories, so a `List<repo>` is the correct type.

trans-unit.source: Add the following line to your `ProcessRepositories` method:
trans-unit.target: Add the following line to your `ProcessRepositories` method:

trans-unit.source: You're using two new namespaces, so you'll need to add those as well:
trans-unit.target: You're using two new namespaces, so you'll need to add those as well:

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll use the serializer to convert JSON into C# objects.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll use the serializer to convert JSON into C# objects.

trans-unit.source: Replace the call to `GetStringAsync()` in your `ProcessRepositories` method with the following two lines:
trans-unit.target: Replace the call to `GetStringAsync()` in your `ProcessRepositories` method with the following two lines:

trans-unit.source: Notice that you're now using `GetStreamAsync` instead of `GetStringAsync`.
trans-unit.target: Notice that you're now using `GetStreamAsync` instead of `GetStringAsync`.

trans-unit.source: The serializer uses a stream instead of a string as its source.
trans-unit.target: The serializer uses a stream instead of a string as its source.

trans-unit.source: Let's explain a couple features of the C# language that are being used in the second line above.
trans-unit.target: Let's explain a couple features of the C# language that are being used in the second line above.

trans-unit.source: The argument to `ReadObject` is an `await` expression.
trans-unit.target: The argument to `ReadObject` is an `await` expression.

trans-unit.source: Await expressions can appear almost anywhere in your code, even though up to now, you've only seen them as part of an assignment statement.
trans-unit.target: Await expressions can appear almost anywhere in your code, even though up to now, you've only seen them as part of an assignment statement.

trans-unit.source: Secondly, the `as` operator converts from the compile time type of `object` to `List<repo>`.
trans-unit.target: Secondly, the `as` operator converts from the compile time type of `object` to `List<repo>`.

trans-unit.source: The declaration of `ReadObject` declares that it returns an object of type `System.Object`.
trans-unit.target: The declaration of `ReadObject` declares that it returns an object of type `System.Object`.

trans-unit.source: will return the type you specified when you constructed it (`List<repo>` in this tutorial).
trans-unit.target: will return the type you specified when you constructed it (`List<repo>` in this tutorial).

trans-unit.source: If the conversion does not succeed, the `as` operator evaluates to `null`, instead of throwing an exception.
trans-unit.target: If the conversion does not succeed, the `as` operator evaluates to `null`, instead of throwing an exception.

trans-unit.source: You're almost done with this section.
trans-unit.target: You're almost done with this section.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've converted the JSON to C# objects, let's display the name of each repository:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've converted the JSON to C# objects, let's display the name of each repository:

trans-unit.source: Compile and run the application.
trans-unit.target: Compile and run the application.

trans-unit.source: It will print out the names of the repositories that are part of the .NET Foundation.
trans-unit.target: It will print out the names of the repositories that are part of the .NET Foundation.

trans-unit.source: Controlling Serialization
trans-unit.target: Controlling Serialization

trans-unit.source: Before you add more features, let's address the `repo` type and make it follow more standard C# conventions.
trans-unit.target: Before you add more features, let's address the `repo` type and make it follow more standard C# conventions.

trans-unit.source: You'll do this by annotating the `repo` type with *Attributes* that control how the JSON Serializer works.
trans-unit.target: You'll do this by annotating the `repo` type with *Attributes* that control how the JSON Serializer works.

trans-unit.source: In your case, you'll use these attributes to define a mapping between the JSON key names and the C# class and member names.
trans-unit.target: In your case, you'll use these attributes to define a mapping between the JSON key names and the C# class and member names.

trans-unit.source: The two attributes used are the `DataContract` attribute and the `Data Member` attribute.
trans-unit.target: The two attributes used are the `DataContract` attribute and the `Data Member` attribute.

trans-unit.source: By convention, all Attribute classes end in the suffix `Attribute`.
trans-unit.target: By convention, all Attribute classes end in the suffix `Attribute`.

trans-unit.source: However, you do not need to use that suffix when you apply an attribute.
trans-unit.target: However, you do not need to use that suffix when you apply an attribute.

trans-unit.source: The `DataContract` and `DataMember` attributes are in a different library, so you'll need to add that library to project.json as a dependency.
trans-unit.target: The `DataContract` and `DataMember` attributes are in a different library, so you'll need to add that library to project.json as a dependency.

trans-unit.source: Add the following line to the dependencies section of the project.json file (remember to add the comma separator on the line above):
trans-unit.target: Add the following line to the dependencies section of the project.json file (remember to add the comma separator on the line above):

trans-unit.source: After you save the file, run 'dotnet restore' to retrieve this package and update the project.json.lock file.
trans-unit.target: After you save the file, run 'dotnet restore' to retrieve this package and update the project.json.lock file.

trans-unit.source: Next, open the repo.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Next, open the repo.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Let's change the name to use Pascal Case, and fully spell out the name `Repository`.
trans-unit.target: Let's change the name to use Pascal Case, and fully spell out the name `Repository`.

trans-unit.source: We still want to map JSON 'repo' nodes to this type, so you'll need to add the `DataContract` attribute to the class declaration.
trans-unit.target: We still want to map JSON 'repo' nodes to this type, so you'll need to add the `DataContract` attribute to the class declaration.

trans-unit.target: YOu'll set the `Name` property of the attribute to the name of the JSON nodes that map to this type:

trans-unit.target: The `DataContractAttribute` is a member of the `System.Runtime.Serialization` namespace, so you'll need to add the appropriate using statement at the top of the file:

trans-unit.target: You changed the name of the `repo` class to `Repository`, so you'll need to make the same name change in Program.cs (some editors may support a rename refactoring that will make this change automatically:)

trans-unit.source: Next, let's make the same change with the `name` field, using the `DataMemberAttribute` class.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's make the same change with the `name` field, using the `DataMemberAttribute` class.

trans-unit.target: Make the following changes to the declaration of the `name` field in repo.cs:

trans-unit.target: This change means you need to change the code that writes the name of each repository in program.cs:

trans-unit.source: Do a "dotnet build", followed by a "dotnet run" to make sure you've got the mappings correct.
trans-unit.target: Do a "dotnet build", followed by a "dotnet run" to make sure you've got the mappings correct.

trans-unit.source: You should see the same output as before.
trans-unit.target: You should see the same output as before.

trans-unit.source: Before we process more properties from the web server, let's make one more change to the `Repository` class.
trans-unit.target: Before we process more properties from the web server, let's make one more change to the `Repository` class.

trans-unit.source: The `Name` member is a publicly accessible field.
trans-unit.target: The `Name` member is a publicly accessible field.

trans-unit.source: That's not a good object oriented practice, so let's change it to a property.
trans-unit.target: That's not a good object oriented practice, so let's change it to a property.

trans-unit.source: For our purposes, we don't need any specific code to run when getting or setting the property, but changing to a property makes it easier to add those changes later without breaking any code that uses the `Repository` class.
trans-unit.target: For our purposes, we don't need any specific code to run when getting or setting the property, but changing to a property makes it easier to add those changes later without breaking any code that uses the `Repository` class.

trans-unit.source: Remove the field definition, and replace it with an *auto-implemented property*:
trans-unit.target: Remove the field definition, and replace it with an *auto-implemented property*:

trans-unit.source: The compiler generates the body of the `get` and `set` accessors, as well as a private field to store the name.
trans-unit.target: The compiler generates the body of the `get` and `set` accessors, as well as a private field to store the name.

trans-unit.source: It would be similar to the following code that you could type by hand:
trans-unit.target: It would be similar to the following code that you could type by hand:

trans-unit.source: Let's make one more change before adding new features.
trans-unit.target: Let's make one more change before adding new features.

trans-unit.source: The `ProcessRepositories` method can do the async work and return a collection of the repositories.
trans-unit.target: The `ProcessRepositories` method can do the async work and return a collection of the repositories.

trans-unit.source: Let's return the `List<Repository>` from that method, and move the code that writes the information into the `Main` method.
trans-unit.target: Let's return the `List<Repository>` from that method, and move the code that writes the information into the `Main` method.

trans-unit.target: Then, just return the repositories after processing the JSON response:

trans-unit.source: The compiler generates the `Task<T>` object for the return because you've marked this method as `async`.
trans-unit.target: The compiler generates the `Task<T>` object for the return because you've marked this method as `async`.

trans-unit.source: Then, let's modify the `Main` method so that it captures those results and writes each repository name to the console.

trans-unit.source: Accessing the `Result` property of a Task blocks until the task has completed.
trans-unit.target: Accessing the `Result` property of a Task blocks until the task has completed.

trans-unit.source: Normally, you would prefer to `await` the completion of the task as in the `ProcessRepositories` method, but that isn't allowed in the `Main` method.
trans-unit.target: Normally, you would prefer to `await` the completion of the task as in the `ProcessRepositories` method, but that isn't allowed in the `Main` method.

trans-unit.source: Reading More Information
trans-unit.target: Reading More Information

trans-unit.source: Let's finish this by processing a few more of the properties in the JSON packet that gets sent from the GitHub API.
trans-unit.target: Let's finish this by processing a few more of the properties in the JSON packet that gets sent from the GitHub API.

trans-unit.source: You won't want to grab everything, but adding a few properties will demonstrate a few more features of the C# language.
trans-unit.target: You won't want to grab everything, but adding a few properties will demonstrate a few more features of the C# language.

trans-unit.source: Let's start by adding a few more simple types to the `Repository` class definition.
trans-unit.target: Let's start by adding a few more simple types to the `Repository` class definition.

trans-unit.source: Add these properties to that class:
trans-unit.target: Add these properties to that class:

trans-unit.source: These properties have built in conversions from the string type (which is what the JSON packets contain) to the target type.
trans-unit.target: These properties have built in conversions from the string type (which is what the JSON packets contain) to the target type.

trans-unit.source: The `Uri` type may be new to you.
trans-unit.target: The `Uri` type may be new to you.

trans-unit.source: It represents a URI, or in this case, a URL.
trans-unit.target: It represents a URI, or in this case, a URL.

trans-unit.source: In the case of the `Uri` and `int` types, if the JSON packet contains data that does not convert to the target type, the Serialization action will throw an exception.
trans-unit.target: In the case of the `Uri` and `int` types, if the JSON packet contains data that does not convert to the target type, the Serialization action will throw an exception.

trans-unit.source: Once you've added these, update the `Main` method to display those elements:
trans-unit.target: Once you've added these, update the `Main` method to display those elements:

trans-unit.source: As a final step, let's add the information for the last push operation.
trans-unit.target: As a final step, let's add the information for the last push operation.

trans-unit.source: This information is formatted in this fashion in the JSON response:
trans-unit.target: This information is formatted in this fashion in the JSON response:

trans-unit.source: That format does not follow one of the standard .NET DateTime formats.
trans-unit.target: That format does not follow one of the standard .NET DateTime formats.

trans-unit.source: Because of that, you'll need to write a custom conversion method.
trans-unit.target: Because of that, you'll need to write a custom conversion method.

trans-unit.source: You also probably don't want the raw string exposed to uses of the `Repository` class.
trans-unit.target: You also probably don't want the raw string exposed to uses of the `Repository` class.

trans-unit.source: Attributes can help control that as well.
trans-unit.target: Attributes can help control that as well.

trans-unit.source: First, define a `private` property that will hold the string representation of the date time in your `Repository` class:
trans-unit.target: First, define a `private` property that will hold the string representation of the date time in your `Repository` class:

trans-unit.source: The `DataMember` attribute informs the Serializer that this should be processed, even though it is not a public member.
trans-unit.target: The `DataMember` attribute informs the Serializer that this should be processed, even though it is not a public member.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to write a public read only property that converts the string to a valid `DateTime` object, and returns that `DateTime`:
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to write a public read only property that converts the string to a valid `DateTime` object, and returns that `DateTime`:

trans-unit.source: Let's go over the new constructs above.
trans-unit.target: Let's go over the new constructs above.

trans-unit.source: The `IgnoreDatamember` attribute instructs the serializer that this type should not be read to or written from any JSON object.
trans-unit.target: The `IgnoreDatamember` attribute instructs the serializer that this type should not be read to or written from any JSON object.

trans-unit.source: This property contains only a `get` accessor.
trans-unit.target: This property contains only a `get` accessor.

trans-unit.source: There is no `set` accessor.
trans-unit.target: There is no `set` accessor.

trans-unit.source: That's how you define a *read only* property in C#.
trans-unit.target: That's how you define a *read only* property in C#.

trans-unit.source: (Yes, you can create *write only* properties in C#, but their value is limited.) The `DateTime.ParseExact` method parses a string and creates a `DateTime` object to return.
trans-unit.target: (Yes, you can create *write only* properties in C#, but their value is limited.) The `DateTime.ParseExact` method parses a string and creates a `DateTime` object to return.

trans-unit.source: If the parse operation fails, the property accessor throws an exception.
trans-unit.target: If the parse operation fails, the property accessor throws an exception.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: This tutorial showed you how to make web requests, parse the result, and display properties of those results.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial showed you how to make web requests, parse the result, and display properties of those results.

trans-unit.source: You've also added new packages as dependencies in your project.
trans-unit.target: You've also added new packages as dependencies in your project.

trans-unit.source: You've seen some of the features of the C# language that support object oriented techniques.
trans-unit.target: You've seen some of the features of the C# language that support object oriented techniques.
